categories.name: Syntax & Compilation
categories.description: Code compiles without errors, proper syntax and language conventions, appropriate use of language features relevant to Variables and Data Types, Functions/Methods, Input/Output Operations, Code Organization, Comments and Documentation, Problem Solving Approaches.

categories.name: Logic & Correctness
categories.description: Algorithm correctness, proper implementation of requirements, handles edge cases appropriately, demonstrates understanding of Variables and Data Types, Functions/Methods, Input/Output Operations, Code Organization, Comments and Documentation, Problem Solving Approaches.

categories.name: Output & Functionality
categories.description: Produces expected output format, meets all functional requirements, handles input/output correctly, demonstrates working solution.

categories.name: Style & Documentation
categories.description: Clear variable and function names, proper indentation and formatting, appropriate comments, follows coding best practices.

category_scores.reasoning: The code compiles without errors, uses standard Java syntax, and correctly implements the class structure and methods. No specific language features were presented that allowed for assessment beyond basic conventions.

The constructors are implemented correctly, including the default constructor invoking the parameterized constructor through `this`. Getter methods are present. However, the `getVolume()` method has an incorrect formula (it should be `l * w * h`, not `l * h`). This directly impacts the logical correctness of the class.

The program creates the two required objects and calls `displayInfo()` for each. The output format attempts to match the requirement, but due to the incorrect `getVolume()` calculation, the volume output is wrong for both cuboids. The surface area calculation is correct.

Variable names (`l`, `w`, `h`, `color`) are concise but could be more descriptive (e.g., `length`, `width`, `height`). Method names are clear. Indentation and formatting are consistent. No comments or documentation were provided, impacting this category significantly.

feedback.overall_comment: The student has provided a working Java program that defines a `Cuboid` class and demonstrates its usage. The code compiles successfully and includes most of the required features such as constructors, getters, and a `displayInfo` method. The default constructor correctly invokes the parameterized constructor. However, there is a critical logical error in the `getVolume()` method, which should be `l * w * h` instead of `l * h`. Additionally, the code lacks comments and uses short variable names, which could be improved for better style and documentation.
strengths: Code compiles and runs without errors.
Both required constructors are implemented correctly.
The default constructor appropriately uses `this` to call the parameterized constructor.
Getter methods are provided for all attributes.
The `displayInfo()` method attempts to print all required information.
The test program creates and uses two `Cuboid` objects as specified.
areas_for_improvement: Correct the `getVolume()` method to use the formula `l * w * h`.
Consider using more descriptive variable names (e.g., `length`, `width`, `height` instead of `l`, `w`, `h`).
Add comments to explain the purpose of the class, its attributes, and methods.
Add Javadoc comments for better documentation.
Ensure all methods fulfill their intended functionality correctly (specifically `getVolume`).

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Formula for Volume
misconceptions.description: The student appears to misunderstand or incorrectly recall the formula for the volume of a cuboid. The implementation `l * h` does not account for the width dimension.

evidence.note: This method incorrectly calculates the volume of the cuboid.

category_scores.reasoning: The code compiles cleanly (no syntax errors, proper Java keywords, correct declarations). Minor deductions: the no-arg constructor should chain with “this(1,1,1,"white")” instead of duplicating assignments, and class comments are absent; these are judged as style rather than hard compilation blockers.

getVolume() incorrectly returns l*h (missing w) – a clear logical/algorithmic error. The no-arg constructor requirement explicitly says “invoke the 4-argument constructor using this”; the submitted version duplicates assignments. These two defects directly break functional correctness and instructions. Surface-area formula and getters are fine.

Because getVolume() multiplies only two dimensions, every printed volume is wrong (expected 20.71 for the green cuboid, prints 47.2; expected 1 for default, prints 1). Functional requirements therefore fail.
Names are clear, indentation/formatting consistent, but no Javadoc/class comments provided and no-arg constructor violates DRY by duplicating literals instead of chaining.

feedback.overall_comment: Your Cuboid class is structurally solid and compiles cleanly, but it contains two critical issues: (1) the getVolume() method omits the width, so every volume calculation is incorrect, and (2) the no-argument constructor should delegate to the 4-argument constructor using this(...) rather than repeating the assignments. Once these are fixed, your program will produce the expected output.
strengths: Clean, readable variable and method names, proper indentation
Correct surface-area formula and getter methods
areas_for_improvement: Fix getVolume() to multiply l * w * h, not l * h
Replace the assignments in the no-arg constructor with: this(1, 1, 1, "white");
Add brief class and method comments (Javadoc style) for clarity

misconceptions.name: Volume formula missing a dimension
misconceptions.description: Student believes cuboid volume equals length × height, omitting width.

evidence.note: getVolume() should multiply l*w*h but only multiplies l*h

misconceptions.name: No-arg constructor delegation
misconceptions.description: Student thinks explicit assignments are equivalent to constructor chaining, not realizing the requirement to call this(...) so the 4-arg constructor centrally handles initialization.

evidence.note: Uses direct field assignment instead of invoking this(1,1,1,"white")
